interlinear-text.item: Told in 1967, 1968, 1969, 1972 by Akbarcho Soultanov, 50-55 years old, schoolmaster in the village of Zmoudg, and in 1968 by Andalieb Kourbounassinov, 40 years old, from the village of Vrang, and by Chabozkhon Karakouchiev, 40 years old, Kolhozian from the village of Langar.

phrase.item: White wool under a tree (a hare)
Big belly at night, sterile during the day (a duvet)
He walks, walks, then comes home and takes up the space of a coin (a stick)
He walks, walks, then comes home and takes up the space of a screen (a dog)
It snowed everywhere, but it did not snow in the king’s house (a river)
Its mouth is closed during the day, and open at night (a boot)
At night, face-down, during the day, on its back. (The skylight in the roof to let smoke out, which is closed at night)
A grey goat swings in a tree (an axe)

An ewe on a slope and a wolf that looks at her from the side (A pancake/flat baked good) (The wolf represents the man looking through the door of the oven at the pancakes baking further away against the walls of the oven)
She clothes the world, but herself is naked. (A needle)
Whose back is your soft filly against?
(The back of a spoon, and in a dish) (The soft filly represents the tongue)
One window on top, two windows at the bottom, climbing on a man’s bottom. (Pants.)
Smaller than a dog, taller than a horse (saddle)
It doesn’t have a soul, but its burden does (horseshoes).
You can feel it, but you can’t see it (the ear)
She goes, goes, then stays with her mouth open (a boot)
On one side a precipice, on the other side a precipice, inside it rattles. (A crib)
